overview: The purpose of this bill is to facilitate more effective enforcement of Hawaii’s fireworks control laws by amending definitions, strengthening and clarifying criminal offenses, and establishing new offenses. [2] The establishment of an adjudication system and procedures to process fireworks infractions represents a significant step forward in addressing the ongoing challenges of illegal fireworks in Hawaii. [2] This bill provides a more robust framework for enforcement and accountability. [2]
agency_impact: The Department of Law Enforcement (DLE) supports the bill but is concerned about the potential repeal of provisions that relate to the DLE’s ability to assist fire departments with conducting inspections of fireworks licenses. [2] [2] Last year, the Legislature acted to give the DLE authority to assist the county fire departments with inspections of fireworks licenses, and the DLE believes that this authority is still needed. [2] [2] The Department of the Attorney General strongly supports this bill and proposes amendments to strengthen its legislative intent, such as adding an offense for throwing or manually propelling ignited fireworks. [2]
policy_impact: Your Committee has amended this measure by amending the offense of general fireworks or articles pyrotechnic prohibitions in the second degree. [3] [4] This amendment includes throwing, catapulting, or otherwise manually propelling ignited aerial devices, articles pyrotechnics, consumer fireworks, or display fireworks as part of the offense. [3] [4] The committee also clarified when the state of mind requirement is not applicable for this offense and clarified the weight thresholds for certain penalties. [4] [4]
revenue_sources: Revenue for this measure will be generated through fines. [2] For a first offense, the carrier or person shall be subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [2] For a second offense committed within five years of a prior judgment, the fine is $2,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt), and for a third or subsequent offense, the fine is $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt). [2] [2] Other violations of this chapter shall be fined no less than $500 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [2] [2]
operating_revenue_impact: The measure is expected to generate operating revenue from penalties for fireworks offenses. [2] These penalties include a $1,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a first offense, a $2,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a second offense, and a $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a third offense. [2] [2] [2] Other violations are subject to a fine of no less than $500 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt). [2] [2]
